title: 105_s896
content: The "Landmine Elimination Act of 1997" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to landmines. Congress found that in 1995, the Senate voted to impose a moratorium on US use of anti-personnel landmines, and in 1996, senior retired US military officers urged the President to ban the production and use of these landmines, stating it would be humane and militarily responsible. In Vietnam, 7,318 US military personnel were killed and 56,783 injured by landmines. In Bosnia, at least 204 soldiers under UN command and 55 soldiers under NATO command were injured or killed by landmines. The Department of State estimates the impact on civilians. Soldiers under NATO command have been injured and 9 killed by landmines. The Department of State estimates that a person is killed or injured by a landmine every 22 minutes. President Clinton declared aggressive pursuit of an international agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines. The Organization of American States declared the goal of a Western Hemisphere landmine free zone. On June 4, 1997, the Organization of African Unity adopted the goal of establishing Africa as an anti-personnel landmine free zone. On October 5, 1996, Canada announced negotiations for a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines to be completed in Ottawa in December 1997. On December 10, 1996, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution to vigorously pursue a ban on landmines. The United States-sponsored resolution passed by a vote of 156-0 (with 10 abstentions) to pursue a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines. Formal negotiations on the Ottawa treaty are set to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The United States could use its international influence to secure support for a binding treaty, enhancing its security. A resolution was passed to pursue a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines, with negotiations set to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The treaty would enhance United States security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against its Armed Forces and civilians. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days outlining alternative actions for such deployments on the Korean Peninsula. The President has the authority to delay the restriction if necessary. The President can delay the restriction on new deployments of anti-personnel landmines on the Korean Peninsula if deemed necessary, by submitting an annual report to Congress certifying the indispensability of such deployments for the defense of the Republic of Korea. The report must also detail efforts made to implement proposed alternatives. The report under subsection (d) shall include efforts to implement proposals for the defense of the Republic of Korea. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "anti-personnel landmine" is defined as a munition designed to detonate by contact with a person, causing harm. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" refer to placing or arming such mines after January 1, 2000. The term "landmines" refers to the emplacement or arming of such mines after January 1, 2000, excluding command-detonated Claymore munitions.
